0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKCN11J2Q8	Lawmakers aim to delay U.S. ceding control of Internet's management	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Critics of a plan for the U.S. government to cede control of the Internet's technical management to other countries might succeed in delaying such a move in Congress
column2: a senior lawmaker said on Tuesday.Senator John Thune
column3: a senior Republican from South Dakota
column4: told reporters lawmakers are ""trying to work out ... what would be effective in terms of slowing this.""The U.S. Commerce Department oversees the Internet's management largely because it was invented in the United States.Some Republican politicians
column5: including Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column6: want to block the handover to global stakeholders
column8: tech experts and public interest advocates.Opponents of the transition said it could stifle online freedom by giving voting rights to authoritarian governments.

column1: Tech companies
column2: technical experts and academics have said the transition is overdue and necessary to keep the Internet open and globally oriented
column3: and that the proposal includes safeguards against any potential abuse by any one country.The plan to transfer oversight of the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers
column4: or ICANN
column5: is set to occur on Oct. 1
column6: unless Congress votes to block the handover. The California-based corporation operates the database for domain names such as .com and .net and their corresponding numeric addresses that allow computers to connect.

column1: The Obama administration approved the transition plan in June.Thune said he would expect language delaying the change to be in a bill to fund the government starting Oct. 1. He expects congressional leaders to finish writing the bill next week.Both houses of the Republican-controlled Congress would then have to vote on the bill and President Barack Obama
column2: a Democrat
column3: would have to sign it for it to become law.

column1: A leading Senate Democrat
column2: however
column3: scoffed at the proposed Internet provision. ""Can Ted Cruz and Republicans dream up any more obscure
column4: irrelevant issues to stop the business of the American government?"" asked Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois
column5: the No. 2 Senate Democrat.There are other outstanding government funding issues also being negotiated by lawmakers
column6: including how much spending should be committed to fighting the Zika virus. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Grant McCool)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-lgbt-north-carolina-idUSKCN11J1VU	Loss of 'March Madness' games could hurt North Carolina governor's re-election bid	"
By Colleen Jenkins
| WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C.

column1: WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C. North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory has weathered negative headlines as jobs
column3: conventions and musical performances were canceled in his state this year to protest a law deemed discriminatory against lesbian
column4: gay
column5: bisexual and transgender people.But news that the Southern state was being stripped of hosting two rounds of the nationally popular ""March Madness"" Division I men's college basketball tournament next spring could prove the law's most damaging fallout yet for the Republican seeking re-election in November
column6: political experts said on Tuesday.""There's one thing you don't do in North Carolina. That is mess with basketball
column9: a political scientist at Catawba College in Salisbury.In addition to the tournament
column10: the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) announced on Monday it would relocate six other championship sporting events from North Carolina for the 2016-17 season.NCAA President Mark Emmert said the move was a ""proverbial no-brainer"" after North Carolina in March became the only U.S. state to require transgender people to use bathrooms in government buildings and public schools that correspond with the sex listed on their birth certificate.The Republican-backed law
column11: known as House Bill 2 or H.B. 2
column12: also blocked local government measures aimed at protecting lesbian
column14: bisexual and transgender people from discrimination.

column1: McCrory signed the measure into law and has continued to defend it as he campaigns for a second four-year term. Several recent opinion polls show him trailing his Democratic opponent
column2: state Attorney General Roy Cooper
column3: who has criticized the incumbent for backing the law despite mounting economic losses.In July
column4: the National Basketball Association yanked its 2017 All-Star Game from Charlotte over objections to H.B. 2.The NCAA's decision will not help McCrory's re-election chances
column5: said Steven Greene
column6: a political science professor at North Carolina State University in Raleigh

column1: He's going to suffer from this the most
column2: Greene said in a phone interview
column3: explaining that most of the Republican state legislators associated with the law represent districts drawn so that Republicans have a good chance of winning elections.Responding on Tuesday to the NCAA's move
column4: McCrory called for a halt to ""economic threats or political retaliation"" while nearly two dozen states challenge an Obama administration policy that calls for public schools to allow transgender students to use the bathrooms of their choice.""The issue of redefining gender and basic norms of privacy will be resolved in the near future in the United States court system for not only North Carolina
column5: but the entire nation
column6: the governor said in a statement.

column1: Around North Carolina
column2: residents and local officials bemoaned the loss of championship events. Polls have shown most voters think the law is hurting the state
column3: which has hosted more Division I men's basketball tournament games than any other.""That's part of North Carolina's heart right there
column4: said Cindy Clodfelter
column6: a retired school counselor in Winston-Salem. ""Anything that messes with my sports
column7: I don't like it.""The mayor of Cary - a town which was to host championship events in women's soccer
column10: but lost all of them to this week's NCAA decision - said it was time for state lawmakers to re-evaluate the law.McCrory ""seems to be doubling down
column11: said Mayor Harold Weinbrecht Jr. ""It will say a lot about our state if he wins or if he loses."" (Reporting by Colleen Jenkins; Editing by Will Dunham and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-doddfrank-idUSKCN11J188	House panel okays Dodd-Frank revamp amid partisan rancor	"
By Lisa Lambert
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A House of Representatives panel on Tuesday approved a proposal to revamp the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law
column2: after a hearing where lawmakers verbally tussled over rules enacted in the aftermath of the 2007-09 financial crisis.The Financial Services Committee voted to send the bill
column3: introduced this summer by committee chairman
column4: Republican Jeb Hensarling
column5: to the full House to consider. No Democrat on the committee voted for the measure
column6: which would allow banks to choose between complying with Dodd-Frank or meeting tougher capital requirements.It would also reorganize the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)
column7: a watchdog created through Dodd-Frank that last week penalized Wells Fargo for creating millions of fake accounts under customers' names.The 2010 Dodd-Frank law
column8: passed in the wake of the financial crisis
column9: has drawn the ire of most banks and Republicans in Congress. They have said Congress went too far in trying to clamp down on Wall Street and the law imposes burdensome requirements and gives regulators too much power.

column1: The CPFB has been a particular target for Republicans
column2: who do not like that it is governed by a single director and say it reaches beyond its authority in enforcement.During the hearing
column3: Democrats cited the Wells case
column4: where the CFPB levied its largest-ever fine of $100 million
column5: criticizing the panel's Republican majority.Democrats said that without Dodd-Frank the U.S. government would have had no tools to fight the widespread fraud
column6: which led to the firing of 5

column1: I am particularly disturbed that this bill would take away the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's ability to penalize companies for practices that are abusive to consumers
column2: said New York's Carolyn Maloney
column3: a Democrat
column4: echoing many in her party. ""The chairman's bill
column5: strips...from the CFPB its authority to punish abusive conduct
column6: which means Wells Fargo would have gotten off even easier.""Meanwhile
column8: the Texas Republican who has advocated creating a five-member commission to govern the CFPB
column9: said the bureau has not been politically neutral and is not transparent.

column1: I remain concerned that many bureau actions demonstrate regulatory paternalism that assumes the American consumer doesn't know how to make choices for themselves
column2: he said at the hearing.Corresponding legislation has not been introduced in the Senate
column3: and Obama would be unlikely to sign the bill even both chambers of the Republican-led Congress passed it. Dodd-Frank is one of the Democratic president's signature pieces of legislation. (Reporting by Lisa Lambert; Editing by Peter Cooney and David Gregorio)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hoffman-idUSKCN11J2JD	LinkedIn's Hoffman: Trump presidency would be 'terrifying' for policy	"
By Deborah M. Todd
| SAN FRANCISCO

SAN FRANCISCO LinkedIn cofounder Reid Hoffman said on Tuesday that Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump would have a ""terrifying"" effect on domestic and foreign policy if elected.The comments came one day after Hoffman published an article on Medium.com pledging support to a CrowdPac crowdfunding campaign that promises to donate to veterans causes if Trump releases his tax returns. Hoffman said in his article that he will match five times the crowdfunded amount to donate up to $5 million. The campaign has raised more than $90

Hoffman told a crowd at TechCrunch Disrupt 2016 in San Francisco that he was ""in denial"" about the possibility of a Trump presidency but encouraged by efforts to hold the candidate accountable. Trump's campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Trump is facing criticism for not releasing tax returns
column2: a political practice that is not required by law but has been done by every White House nominee since 1973. His campaign last week released 10 years of returns for vice presidential nominee Mike Pence and repeated a pledge that Trump would release his own returns once the government completes an audit.""When I saw the campaign ... I said that's exactly the right way to make this message
column3: a message in support of folks who have given great service to our country. If Donald Trump is as concerned with making America great as he says he is he should care about veterans
column4: Hoffman said.

column1: (Reporting by Deborah M. Todd; Editing by Meredith Mazzilli)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-economy-idUSKCN11J25M	Trump presidency could cost U.S. economy $1 trillion: Oxford Economics	"
LONDON The U.S. economy could be $1 trillion smaller than otherwise expected in 2021 if Republican candidate Donald Trump wins the presidential election in November
column2: economics research firm Oxford Economics said on Tuesday.While the firm said Trump's policies - including more protectionist trade measures
column3: tax cuts and mass deportation of illegal immigrants - may be watered down in negotiations with Congress
column4: they could have ""adverse"" consequences. ""Should Mr. Trump prove more successful in achieving adoption of his policies
column5: the consequences could be far-reaching - knocking 5 percent off the level of U.S. GDP relative to baseline and undermining the anticipated recovery in global growth
column6: it said.Oxford Economics describes itself as an independent global advisory firm. It is headquartered in Oxford
column8: but has offices around the world
column12: San Francisco and Washington.The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the research. At a campaign event in Clive
column16: Trump reasserted that he would grow the U.S. economy.

column1: He vowed to revive the country's manufacturing sector by preventing U.S. companies such as Apple Inc from making products overseas
column2: renegotiating global trade accords and slashing federal taxes and regulations.""We're going to provide opportunity
column3: prosperity and security for all Americans
column4: Trump said.Under its baseline scenario
column5: Oxford Economics expects U.S.  gross domestic product
column6: the value of all goods and services produced in the economy
column7: to grow at a fairly constant rate of around 2 percent from 2017

column1: But if Trump is elected and succeeds in implementing his policies
column2: it predicts growth would slow significantly
column3: falling near zero in 2019
column4: and reducing overall GDP to $17.5 trillion. Oxford Economics said its baseline scenario assumes Trump's Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton triumphs in the Nov. 8 vote and a split Congress emerges - between a Republican U.S. House of Representatives and a Democratic U.S. Senate - which results largely in a continuation of current policies.

column1: Trump would face challenges winning the backing of Congress for all his policies
column2: and some economists argue that looser tax policy could actually help boost economic growth.The latest opinion polls show Clinton
column3: the former secretary of state
column4: ahead
column5: but her lead has slipped in recent weeks. (Reporting by John Geddie; Additional reporting by James Oliphant in Des Moines
column6: Iowa; Editing by Howard Goller and Dan Grebler)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-saudi-idUSKCN11J2JF	Democrats expect Senate will oppose Obama on Saudi 9/11 bill	"

WASHINGTON The Democratic leaders of the U.S. Senate said on Tuesday they expected the chamber would vote to override President Barack Obama's promised veto of a bill allowing relatives of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia.It would be the first override of an Obama veto since he took office in January 2009.The ""Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act
column2: known as JASTA
column3: would remove sovereign immunity
column4: preventing lawsuits against governments
column5: for countries found to be involved in terrorist attacks on U.S. soil.Fifteen of the Sept. 11 hijackers who crashed airliners in the 2001 attacks were Saudi nationals. The Saudi government
column6: which strongly denies responsibility

column1: But some members of Congress have become increasingly restive about relations with Saudi Arabia
column2: long an important player in U.S. Middle East policy.Harry Reid
column3: the Senate's Democratic leader
column4: said he supported the measure. ""They're not one of my favorite countries
column5: he said of the Saudis.

column1: Richard Durbin
column2: the No. 2 Senate Democrat
column3: said
column4: ""We're all on the record supporting it
column5: so at this point I think it's a heavy lift for the president to have his veto sustained.""A White House spokesman said in a briefing on Tuesday it had received the bill
column6: but did not offer updates about timing of a veto. The Constitution gives the president 10 days after receiving a bill to veto it before it automatically becomes law.

column1: (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle and Richard Cowan; Additional reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-guantanamo-idUSKCN11J2IA	Obama would veto House bill to block funding of Guantanamo transfers: White House	"

WASHINGTON President Barack Obama's advisers would recommend he veto a bill in the House of Representatives that prohibits use of funds to transfer individuals detained at the Guantanamo Bay military prison to the United States or any foreign country
column2: the White House said on Tuesday. The bill was introduced in the House and is making its way through Congress. It faces a tough battle in the Senate. Operation of the prison ""weakens our national security by draining resources
column3: damaging our relationships with key allies and partners
column4: and emboldening violent extremists
column5: the White House said in a release.

column1: (Reporting by Timothy Gardner; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cyber-idUSKCN11J2DD	Spy agencies concerned about possible U.S. election hacks: NSA chief	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON American intelligence agencies are concerned about reports that foreign governments may be attempting to undermine the Nov. 8  U.S. elections through cyber attacks
column2: Admiral Mike Rogers
column3: the director of the National Security Agency
column4: said on Tuesday.""We continue to be actively concerned
column5: Rogers told a Senate hearing
column6: responding to a question from Senator John McCain
column7: chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.Marcel Lettre
column8: Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence
column9: testified that the government is taking any such activities ""quite seriously"" and said an ""aggressive investigation"" is under way.McCain noted that one of the two states in which media reports said there was evidence of attempted Russian hacking was his home state
column11: which recently has been reliably Republican in presidential elections
column12: could be tilting more toward the Democratic nominee
column16: himself is in a tougher than usual re-election fight.

column1: Rogers said he could not provide specifics about spy agencies' current assessment of the alleged hacking in a public setting. But he added
column2: ""I will say this
column3: that it continues to be an issue of great focus ... for the foreign intelligence community
column4: attempting to generate insights into what foreign nations are doing in this area.""Under further questioning
column5: Rogers declined to characterize the activity as by a foreign nation-state.

column1: Lettre said the government would adopt a policy for dealing with any such activity once it had the results of the investigation.""The FBI and the Department of Homeland Security has an aggressive investigation underway
column2: Lettre said.U.S. security officials have said that
column3: starting last year
column4: hackers infiltrated computers of the Democratic National Committee
column5: Clinton's presidential campaign and her party's congressional fundraising committee.

column1: U.S. officials said they have concluded that Russia or its proxies were responsible
column2: leading to calls by some Democrats and cyber security officials for the Obama administration to blame Russia publicly.Kremlin officials have dismissed the allegations as absurd
column3: but there is anxiety in Washington over the possibility that a foreign power might be using hacked information to meddle in the November elections. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN11J28T	Hillary Clinton's overdrive aimed at breaking women's glass ceiling	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON It was classic Hillary Clinton
column2: ignoring medical advice and attending a ceremony on a sultry New York City day while battling pneumonia - a decision ex-aides and other associates speculated was rooted in her longstanding desire to prove that women can compete in the male-dominated world of politics.The move backfired on the famously stoic Democratic presidential candidate after she had to leave Sunday's September. 11 remembrance early and was caught on camera buckling from dehydration as she was helped into a van. Clinton
column4: has since acknowledged she went too far in trying to soldier on with a jam-packed schedule.Daniel Scherb
column5: a South Bend
column6: Indiana
column8: who was not privy to Clinton's medical records
column9: said pneumonia can leave a patient ""feeling blah for seven to 10 days"" under the best of circumstances and
column11: ""people can die from it.""Former subordinates who are fiercely loyal to Clinton said there are plenty of instances in which she drove herself remarkably hard as first lady from 1993-2001
column12: as a U.S. senator from 2001-2009 and as U.S. secretary of state from 2009-2013.In her first year at the State Department in 2009
column13: she traveled abroad extensively shortly after undergoing surgery for a broken arm.One retired ambassador said Clinton sees herself as part of a generation of women who had to work extra hard to overcome barriers to female advancement. The ambassador describes this as part of an ethos that ""you could never be weaker than a man.""At the same time
column14: the ambassador blamed Clinton's aides in part for allowing her to put herself into difficult situations.

column1: 'A DIFFERENT LENS'
At an event in Congo after breaking her arm
column2: Clinton snapped at someone who posed a question she disliked
column3: the ambassador recalled. While the question may have been translated into English incorrectly
column4: the ambassador said Clinton also was clearly exhausted.""It's not necessarily that she is running roughshod over the advice of her staff. Her staff doesn't seem to take very good care of her
column5: the ambassador said.Working to defeat Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column8: Clinton has said she is held to a different standard.""Women are seen through a different lens
column9: Clinton told Humans of New York
column10: a group organized around a project to photograph and catalog stories of New Yorkers.

column1: I've learned that I can't be quite so passionate in my presentation
column2: she said
column3: adding
column4: ""I love to wave my arms
column5: but apparently that's a little bit scary to people. And I can't yell too much. It comes across as 'too loud' or 'too shrill' or 'too this' or 'too that
column6: '"" even though those attending her rallies ""are loving it.""In all her roles
column7: including as President Bill Clinton's healthcare chief and a two-time presidential candidate
column8: Clinton has been known as an almost unstoppable
column10: internal in meetings or external on Capitol Hill
column13: a White House deputy communications director during Bill Clinton's first term.Dreyer
column14: who said he had a ""front row seat"" to the healthcare reform fight that Hillary Clinton spearheaded as first lady
column15: said she is ""wired"" to always be fully prepared and compelled to public service.

column1: 'CAN'T-WIN SITUATION'
Three other people
column2: one close to Clinton when she was secretary of state and as a presidential candidate
column3: said efforts to persuade her to temper her travel and appearance schedule can go nowhere because she insists it is expected of her.One
column4: a prominent former official who has advised Clinton on foreign policy issues
column5: said: ""She pushes herself so hard because she's convinced that only she can do what needs to be done
column6: and that's compounded by a very small inner circle that in some cases doesn't like to contradict or confront her
column7: and as a result just ends up encouraging this compulsion.""Matt Bennett
column8: who served as deputy assistant for intergovernmental affairs in Bill Clinton's second presidential term
column9: said Hillary Clinton is ""in a can't-win situation here."" Noting competing
column10: unsubstantiated attacks from Trump and his supporters about her health versus criticisms that she does not know how to pace herself
column11: ""Either she is frail or reckless with her health.""Bennett added
column12: ""I don't view her as disregarding medical advice"" over past blood clots
column13: a fall that caused a concussion and other maladies. ""But I do think she's super tough.""Bennett
column14: now a vice president at the Third Way think tank
column15: said the increasingly frantic pace of campaigning for the White House has pressed candidates to the limit.As an aide to retired General Wesley Clark while he unsuccessfully sought the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004
column16: Bennett noted that Clark would constantly remark about the rigors of the campaign. ""He was shot multiple times in Vietnam and went through (elite Army) Ranger training and he's saying this is really tough running for president."" (Additional reporting by John Walcott and Amanda Becker; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Howard Goller)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKCN11J14A	Paul Ryan's challenges will not start until after Nov. 8 election	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan is expected to cruise to re-election in his Wisconsin congressional district on Nov. 8
column2: the day before his real political problems are likely to start.That is when Ryan will know the shape of the new House of Representatives. If
column3: as some analysts foresee
column4: it becomes even more conservative than it is now
column5: Ryan's difficulties in managing the lower chamber of Congress could worsen.For the highest-ranking elected U.S. Republican
column6: that could spell trouble as the former vice presidential nominee looks ahead to a possible presidential run in 2020.Some staunch House conservatives
column7: questioning Ryan's commitment to them and their agenda
column8: are looking less kindly on the idea of re-electing him as speaker early next year.But his real test
column9: assuming he retains the speaker's gavel
column10: would be getting legislative results with a more conservative House. Compounding that could be the U.S. Senate switching to Democratic from Republican control and possibly a Democratic president
column12: if she beats Republican Donald Trump in the November election.""Next year
column14: is going to be a very tough one for Paul Ryan
column15: said political scientist Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute think tank.The 2016 election results could cast a shadow over Ryan's presidential ambitions in 2020 and 2024
column16: assuming he harbors them. ""It may well be that he decides it's just not worth it
column17: partly given what he sees within his own party
column18: Ornstein said.Ryan's aides were reluctant on Monday to discuss the possible challenges of the next Congress.

column1: The focus over the next 57 days is defending and strengthening our House majority. We are in a good position
column2: said Ryan's political spokesman
column3: Zack Roday.SMALLER
column4: MORE CONSERVATIVE CAUCUS?

column1: Republicans hold 246 of the 435 House seats
column2: their biggest majority in decades. But analysts expect the party will lose seats in November
column3: especially if Trump hurts fellow Republicans.

column1: House members serve two-year terms and most are easily re-elected. The political prediction newsletter ""Sabato's Crystal Ball"" has tagged only 16 races as too close to call. Ten of those are currently held by moderates or pragmatists who have been fairly reliable supporters of legislation backed by Republican leaders including Ryan. Five of the 10 are retiring from the House.If Trump's performance damages candidates down the ticket
column2: moderates may bear the brunt. The result could be a smaller House Republican majority more dominated by politically secure conservatives of the sort who have in recent years defied Ryan on some legislation.""A shrinking GOP conference is no doubt going to be more conservative in the new Congress
column3: raising the challenge for Speaker Ryan to form majorities with a slimmer and more conservative rank and file
column4: said Sarah Binder
column5: professor of political science at George Washington University.If a number of moderates lose their seats
column6: while most conservatives hold theirs
column7: ""then the House Freedom Caucus becomes more powerful

column1: The Freedom Caucus is the House's most conservative bloc
column2: with about 40 members. It helped eject Ryan's predecessor
column3: John Boehner
column4: a year ago
column5: leading to Ryan's election as speaker.The Freedom Caucus initially welcomed Ryan
column6: a budget and fiscal policy specialist seen as more willing to listen to their agenda. But some Freedom Caucus members are unhappy with him since one of their members
column8: lost a primary election last month.Ryan could have done more to help Huelskamp
column9: some critics said. ""There was huge disappointment in that
column11: a Freedom Caucus member from Louisiana who is running for the U.S. Senate in November.The Huelskamp fallout has driven speculation that some conservatives who previously backed Ryan will oppose him when the House elects a new speaker in January
column12: although none of them has said so publicly.""I don't think most members feel yet that Ryan is undeserving of more time (as speaker)
column13: but frustration with the leadership is certainly growing
column14: said Dan Holler of Heritage Action
column15: the political wing of the Heritage Foundation conservative think tank. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Peter Cooney)"
